Name: Higgs Discovery: The Power of Empty Space

ReviewList.Text: I have a background in Computer Science, and had studied physics in school. I have also read a lot of popular physics books by John Gribbin, Stephen Hawkings etc. However, I must say that I understood very little in this book. As an attempt to explain Higg's Boson and its significance to a layman it fails in its task. As a scientifically accurate document, I must say it won't appeal to someone who already knows a bit of science. In short, it fails to appeal to both the layman and the knowledgeable.

Not much new here. When the minuscule sub atomic particles of new meat are exhausted, the author resorts to a reprinting of several chapters of her previous work. The reason this book is priced at the bargain basement price of $2.99 (Kindle) is because it is not worth a penny more and dollars less. If you are completely bored and have read every other new scientific work available, this may be a companion, but not one you're likely to ever pick up to re-read.

I have an avid interest in quantum physics, sparked by books like 'The Tao of Physics', 'Dancing Wu Li Masters', and 'Stalking the Wild Pendulum'.  I hoped this book would help me understand what happened in the LHC.  However, I found it too complicated and not as easy to grasp as the books mentioned here.  Hope to come across a simpler book that nevertheless will explain the Higgs field for the absolute layman.

Generally well written...very short. It placed the higgs "out there" without discussing or implying the potential implications that science might proceed with. Too soon, too short, too matter of fact.

I found this play-by-play account to be a bit verbose and unfocused. I would have preferred more sidebars describing the physics, and less "then this happened and then that happened" type commentary. I put it down after about 20-30 pages.
The book does not describe how the Higgs field came to be.  Brian Greene's book "The fabric of the cosmos" does that, assuming it is correct.  One should read the Greene book first.

A brief history of the Higgs Boson, Particle, Field etc, about what the discovery is and isn't, and a hint of what might come next.  No math involved.  Also includes a revelant chapter from two of the authors books.  Worth reading if you are curious beyond the hype, or enjoy keeping up with science.

This is a very poorly wriiten book. There's no apparent organization (at least none that I can see).  In general, the paragraphs have little or no coherence & continuity. The text comes across random babbling in many parts. The grammar is atrocious. Most of the book is recycled word-for-word from two of her earlier books. I'm surprised that the author has such deficient writing skills. I cannot recall EVER reading a more poorly written popular science book. How long did it take to write the 'book'? Was there any editing? My former high school teachers would have given the professor an "F" on this assignment!

My favorite science reading is astro-physics.I have read over 20 books about this.The book that started my interest in this was Lisa Randall's Warped Passages,continued on with Knocking on Heaven's Door and then Higgs Discovery.She is my favorite physics author and not only the Standard Model expert,she can report her thoughts about the latest discoveries in a style that even I can understand!!!

This wonderful update from Professor Randall does not disappoint.  She gives us the "real deal" on the Higgs-type particle discovered at the LHC.  I am lucky to have both of her recent books on the subject, which I perused carefully.  I underlined her forecast of 125 GEV mass of the Higgs and looked excitedly over the intervening months for further word from CERN on status of the search.  Imagine my awe at learning that very energy level is attached to the new boson!  Thank you SO MUCH Professor for providing this update to us, your thirsty audience.  I can say my toes wiggled in delight while reading this update.  Better, I actually understood the conversation, thanks to the careful explanations found in Warped Passages and her later book, Knocking on Heaven's Door.  Best of all, exciting discoveries lie immediately on the horizon - stay tuned!  Please continue to inform us, Professor, and thank you.

At the price it was OK but having read "Knocking on Heaven's Door by Lisa Randall (which was very informative and well illustrated) I found that after reading "Higgs Discovery" I did not fully understand the significance of the Higgs mechanism.

I was a bit glazed over by all the theoretical discussion in this book - but hey - that's physics! I had hoped for a more "layman" friendly book about this particle - but it is well written, none the less.

Not organized.  The book contains a lot of personal information that personally I don't really want to known. Also she jumps from one subject to the other assuming that the reader know physics very well
Some of the concepts of quantum mechanics are explained, and the CERN experimental data is explained well enough for a lay person to grasp the significance of Bosons, and anti-matter.

An insightful view into the world of quantum mechanics and particle accelerators. This book describes the concepts behind the Higgs Boson discovery, what scientists were looking for, and why we should care. It also give a peek into the excitement among  quantum physicists as they unravel part of the mystery behind particle mass, and set back to the books to review the theorems on the calculated weight of the Higgs particle. This book also provided a deeper understanding and was a fortuatous read at the time of finding the documentary "particle fever".

I rate this three stars because I read three-star ratings. The story of the Higgs Discovery was difficult because of the technical-physics explanations. (I have some physics background.) Aside from that, Randall's explanations of fields and the Higgs mechanism were good, simple enough for the layman to understand, and enlightening. This is a quick read; don't try to grasp all the physics, just take what you can.

Although it was smaller than I expected, which probably explains the price, it was informative and not too technical for a layman to benefit from. I have always been impressed with Lisa Randall's writing. She covers a difficult subject in an open and understandable manner and I wanted this book to further explain the Higgs Boson discovery. I felt that it did.
A very good book for the lay-person to understand quantum and particle physics. I have read many books on subject, but this is the best. It is as hard to put down as Clancey thriller.

Interesting topic, but written in quite technical way.  Also, I felt that the book put a lot of emphasis on the anouncement of the discovery and the author's feeling regarding the discovery, but relatively little on the explanation how the Higgs particle works and why it is so important.

K.I.S.S. (Keeping it Simple for us who are Stupid)  Great, easy read for anyone who marginally understands quantum anything.  I would strongly recommend this book as a starting place to grasp the next direction physics is heading off to.  I would suspect that when we find out the power of/in empty space we will be amazed.

For the price I thought this would be more of a book instead of a short story. The relevant part of the discovery consisted of 48 pages on my 6" kindle at number 3 font. Consider how little information that is in a normal book format.

I had expected much higher plane in the discussions, frankly I was a bit disappointed. Higgs discovery is discovery of the century as it allows human science a bit nearer to the greatest secret, that is infusion of life on the earth.
Less than satisfying explanation.
that made this one hard to follow. It was cobbled together from her preceding work with some new information thrown in relative to the observation of the Higgs boson. The result was pretty confusing.
Ms. Randall is a well known scientist who happens to write in a maner that everyone can understand. She makes a complex and difficult subject comprehensive and estimupating even for a non-scients.

The verification of the existence of the higgs boson with high confidence by the LHC is one of the most important scientific findings on the 21st century so far.  Predicted the in 1960s by Peter Higgs, the higgs field, mechanism and associated boson would in great part explain the masses of the elementary particles.  Lisa Randall takes a very technical subject and turns it into physics for everyone - even people who can't (or won't) do math.  No, you won't *understand* the physics involved, but you'll be able to grasp its importance and its implications to advancing the frontiers of physics in the coming years when the LHC will operate at full power.  Should you read this Kindle Short?  Well, if science to you is all about making a better toaster, then no.  You should go through life clueless about the nature of the universe you live in in.  However, if you long to get a handle of why reality is the way it is, you'll get an appreciable amount of satisfaction from reading anything that Lisa Randall writes, because she doesn't dumb down the physics concepts.  She explains the limitations of her analogies and cleans up any misconceptions that they might cause.  She makes it clear that a lack of mathematical treatment of the subject matter severely limits the depths of the subject matter, but takes care bring the mathematically uninitiated as far along as possible.
A very good attempt. I may be too non-technical to understand much of it, but it was valuable. Anyone who wants to understand the latest position of quantum mechanics would like to book.
I'm sure that this book has a lot of good information, but it was hard for me to understand, even though I've been reading physics books and articles for a number of years.
This is a short but thorough discussion of the latest information on the recent discovery at LHC. It helps if you've read Lisa's previous writings on particle physics.
It was okay but the cotent was a kind of vague not so clear to understand the aftermath. But it worth it to read and obtain some good and new information.
Could  never make the concept of HIGGS  so I a layman could truly comprehend.  Could try to repeat and review concept for understanding
This is only a repeat of two books one before Higgs and one after Higgs. I was looking for more on the after the discovery.

Lisa Randall no doubt is a genius, because this reads as if she knocked it off over the weekend and mailed it in.  I am sure explaining high level physics to a general audience is tough, but this reads as if she herself couldn't figure out what level she wanted to hit and her compromise doesn't make it - alternating between great redundancy in stating (and restating, and...) some ideas, and impenetrability, or superficiality in treating others.  A poor balance.  The impression is that this was designed to catch the wave of excitement about the Higg's, with the priority being given to getting it out quickly, at the cost of a better, more thoughtfully written book.  Would have benefited from stronger editorial oversight maybe, but for me this was tantalizing but ultimately unsatisfying.

The book is actually only 40 pages long and is only an advertisement for the author's other two books.  After page 40 the author kindly includes two chapters from the other books as a commercial preview.  The actual content of the book is written poorly and only scratches the surface of an immensely complicated subject that should be exciting but comes across as dull.  Borrow this from a public library if you must read it, but don't pay even a penny for it.
Understandable! Not a lot of material but covered well.
THIS BOOK'S SPOT ON!!
Love to read about the latest in science and this book, 'Higgs Discovery' or God Particle, was fascinating and explained it in great detail.
Good fast response job. Doctor Randall pulls fewer punches in explaining the  excitement around the Higgs' announcement than does the main stream media.
I understood so much more about the Higgs boson and the Higgs field after reading this book. Really an enjoyable read.
Make clear a difficult subject. I have read her other two books and have enjoyed them immensely. I recommend this series to all my friends and family.

Very well written account of the exciting moments leading to the announcement of the discovery of the Higgs boson. It has two chapters from previous books that complement the main text very nicely. I highly recommend it.
I enjoyed reading about the Higgs particle/field, the topic was clearly explained, can't wait to hear what new discoveries will be made when the performance of the LHC is improved.
A difficult topic to understand (for me) but the author has made it, step by step, very clear and if not easy then at least easier to understand.
This book is pretty technical, but if you are into astrophysics it delivers. I found it extremely interesting and I highly recommend it.
Randall does a great job of explaining the complex with a great deal of simplicity. Just wish that there were more answers and less questions.
A very good synopsis of an exciting discovery, Hopefully it will lead to more breakthroughs in the years to come.
It's a little history surrounding the construction of the LHC; its' purposes, goals, and a  little look at the personalities involved in its' development.

This little book covers material of unimaginable complexity. My thinking is not up to all of it, but I have learned so very much from this careful introductory explanation for the educated general public about the nature of what we call "empty space" - which, of course, is not empty at all - and the overwhelming delight of the scientists whose discovery of this new particle validated years of research. I now need a breather, but I plan to return to the topic and venture into a  more comprehensive treatment. By the way, I have seen Dr. Randall on a panel on this topic on Charlie Rose. She is not only brilliant but also gorgeous. Talk about having it all!

This is an interesting book, in several ways.  As a part of my own research, I have read a good deal of Einstein and his contemporaries (and the problem of "the ether" in Cosmology).  Randall explores what the L-H-C experiments have provided us in the search for the Higgs boson (the mechanism that gives objects mass)  As a side benefit Randall also explains why light functions as it does..  While there are a few spots where the science gets a little hard for me to keep my head around; the book does a great job of explaining what the discovery will mean.  Until the L-H-C restarts in 2015, this is a great book to get ready for confirmation.
A recap of latest information coming out of CERN as well as excerpts of previously published information on the background of Higgs probability

I read this as a follow-up to her previous book, which discussed the search for the Higgs Boson. Her approach to explaining very a difficult subject makes it all much less difficult to comprehend. totally recommend her work to anyone interested in physics.

Although my dad was a physics major and my brother is a mathematician, I have avoided theories and etc like the plague.  The Higgs Boson caught my attention on the news and brought me somehow to this book.  It is totally readable and understandable!  I really thank Lisa Randall, who was a part of the discovery process, for writing this book.

With so much talk, recently, on the Higgs Particle I was interested in reading something about it. My knowledge of particle physics is extremely limited but I found most of this book understandable. But I admit some parts of this book were beyond my understanding. Still I recommend this book for some of the interesting facts that are mentioned.
This book gave me a wonderful introduction of what might lie ahead in our ultimate quest to find out why we are here
I enjoyed reading about the Higgs particle and how it creates mass.  If you are interested in science, you will enjoy thios book.

Quick update by a writer who can explain physics in readable language without condescension. Writing in the sciences for the non scientist has improved dramatically over the last decade or so. Lisa Randall is one of the best. There is no excuse for those of us who lack a PhD in specialized fields, like particle physics, to remain in the dark any longer. For my money, it's an exciting time to be a reader.

This is an informative presentation of the Higgs Discovery and the power of empty space.  A model with two Higgs Fields is described.  One gets or has a charge which is uniformly distributed throughout space.

Dr. Randall's quick response to the discovery (confirmation) of the Higgs makes this an excellent source of relevant information for the non-scientist.  The addenda of chapters from her previous book deliver excellent background.
As the author herself points out, this was written on the fly just after the discovery, and intended as a place-holder until she could write a book about it. Wait for the book

I read this book just to have information directly from one of the best scientifics nowadays in physics. Very well written and very usefull for experts and NON experts. I would say I am in the first group, I undestand what L.Randall explain in this book and I find it is full of good writing, ideas and information.

This book covers the Higgs discovery in enough detail where you do not feel like you're being talked down to, however the book itself is a hodgepodge of information.  The book is broken up into three parts; the first covering what the LHC actually discovered but the other two being chapters from her previous books word for word.  Having read one of the two of these, this addition was not very useful.  It would have been nice if she added sections into this that discussed how the opinions (mentioned in these chapters) have changed since the discovery instead of leaving it as though the discovery had not occurred.

Although trained as an engineer, and having taken courses in physics (many years ago), I had no idea what the Higgs Boson was, or what the Higgs Field was, before reading this book. I found the explanations understandable, although I admit,one might need some familiarity with physics before the explanations can be digested. It helps to know what the "standard model is," but I think you can get that appreciation from something like wikipedia.
Difficult to stay interested ..  Maybe it's me, but I found the subject very interesting, but when I dove into the book, I was finding myself trying hard to stay focused.

This was a bit disappointing as there was equal if not more space devoted to Dr. Randall's prior writings.  It is more like an addendum to "Knocking on Heaven's Door.  The latter is well written.  This is more technical than her previous books.  Good read if the reader is somewhat knowledgable about the subject.

What can I say? I bought this book because it came out about three minutes after the Higgs was discovered. The author clearly establishes her bona-fides and makes it pretty readable. But like all of these books, you gotta be ready for the physics-speak.
It is not for the average layman. You should have a fair knowledge of Quantum physics to get the most out of it.

I have a keen interest in science and have dozens of books for the non-scientist on many current topics and have found most of them understandable to varying degrees. This topic is the most esoteric and the most I could get was a general idea of the book so I wouldn't have spent the money if I knew that.
I enjoy Lisa Randall's way of explaining the very complicated concept.  She is able to explain the Higgs Particle and how it works in a way that I can understand.
Lisa Randal can bring to the layman technical information and make it understandable, even to the average person. I enjoy all of her work. She is exceptionally intelligent and very attractive.

With all due respect, this seems to be a rough draft.  With a subject so abstract - the Higgs boson, the Higgs field, and the Higgs mechanism revealed indirectly via multiple teams at the LHC - I think much polish is needed to make this intelligible in a "popular" way.  It may not be possible.  Then make it more coherent.  And less autobiographical.  From the title, I was hoping to learn about "Empty Space," as in does the Higgs field arise out of empty space as waves, the complement of Higgs bosons, a wave-particle duality?  Basics, rather than a personal social calendar at the time of discovery.

The Higgs Boson has been covered in the press making it one of the sexiest particles alive.  It has been called the God Particle for its role in forming mass from energy.  In this meticulous book, the author explains the science behind the hype.  It is not an easy book, but it is an accessable book.  For this reason I would recommend it.  After all, headlines are nice, but the actual research is better.

I've got multiple degrees, love science and math, and am considered a nerd among my friends and family, but even for me this book lacked drive and a compelling writing style.  I know we're talking about particles and such, but I expected a bit more when it comes to the writing style.

I like Randal's work, enough that I own her other two books, "Warped Passages" and "Knocking on Heaven's Door".  Problem is, that I clicked 'buy' on this book before I looked and realized that it is three chapters, two of which are from those two previous works.  I'm sure it's very good, but I feel like I overpaid for something I already own.
Her timely explanations and concise, cogent writing are precisely what was required for the exegesis of the Higgs Boson discovery.
Excellent. Very understandable. Lisa Randall does a great job explaining what the Higgs boson is , explaining the Higgs mechanism, and the Higgs field. I enjoyed reading this book.
It isn't every day thatg someone like me can understand something as complicated as subatomic space, but Lisa Randal has been able to explain the Higgs Bosen in very understandable article.

Unfortunately this book was very disappointing. Only about half the book is new material written after the Higgs Discovery. The book includes several sections from previous books from the same author, to fluff up the pages. In general, the topic is treated in a very pop culture fashion. The author tries to simplify things so much that valuable information is lost along the way. I'd say you'd be better off just reading the news and some Stephen Hawking books. I'm glad I paid very little for it.

Makes very complex subject matter easier to comprehend, but it's still a difficult read, requiring much on-line research to re-inforce Randall's description. Definitely recommend it for someone wanting to know what's going on at CERN.

A concise and comprehensible account of how the existence of the Higgs boson and, provisionally, the Higgs mechanism was inferred from the LHC's data. Read the appendices  excerpted from Randall's Warped Passages and Knocking on Heaven's Door first if you're not familiar with the role of the Higgs in the standard model of particle physics
This is a brief, well-written account of the current state of knowledge about the Higgs field (and its particle, the Higgs boson).  Fun reading!
If you a lay person who doesn't mind reading something four or five times (I don't) this is a good summary

This text is a brief explanation of some new ideas in Physics. Professor Randall does a masterful job of explaining ideas that are actually quite hard to get around. her other books are equally successful at explaining these ideas. Her best work, however, is on the Charlie Rose interview show.
I really enjoyed reading the latest news about this magnificent boson but It would have been great if there was more technical data. Great book

Professor Randall is physicist welling to think beyond the ridge mind set of others,If you will "out of the box".This flexibility in thinking has won her many deserved accolades.Further it is the only way to solve problems which have resisted conventional solution set. I thank her for another insightful view into that process. It is what makes her the astounding accomplished physicist that she is. Thank you professor Randall  for writing another great book.
If it's truly  HIGGS,and from what I have read to date, it's an assumption right now. However if proven,it's going to turn Physics around and leave a lot of the community out on a limb.
I kept waiting for the "reason" for all this research.  Burning questions in my mind, "will this make energy, as we know it today, obsolete?"

I got my Higgs discovery as a Kindal text. There's a major conflict to an understanding of the Higgs Boson concept as it really is right over the heads of most readers. Having said that if you are going to understand the concept involved with out advanced Physics education then Lisa Randall is your best option. The text is written as well as can be expected given the subject, even I got a little insight of the general meaning of the discovery.
This booklet brings clarity to what was discovered and how it was found. I recommend Warped Passages to those who wish to more fully understand the present state of particle physics.

Assumes some knowledge about particle theory and The grand theory of everything, so some parts are quite heavy-going. But all in all an efficient and readable introduction to the theory and recent findings on the Higgs particle
When a history of great discoveries in physics is written hundreds of years from now this will be one of the most quoted and insightful accounts of early 21st century.
This book is very much right to the point if you want to get up to speed in what the Higgs is about.
I found this kindle book very informative and interesting reading. It is a science book well written for easy understanding.

This was a very well written and informative paper about the recent Higgs discovery at CERN in Switzerland.  The Author is careful to point out that the discovery is very preliminary and still subject to more testing before it can be announced with certainty that the Higgs Boson has been discovered, but she also points out that the current evidence is very strong, and in the range that they would expect for this particle.  She gives some brief history of the search for this particle, and discusses its importance in the world of particle physics.  Well worth the read.
Some of the most labyrinthine concepts in contemporary physics are, for the layman, elucidated to an extraordinary degree. A fine sequel to the author's earlier books.
I was curious to learn something about the phenomenon of this new discovery but the book was too detailed and couched in such scientific  language  that I lost interest quickly.
good quick review and statement of the importance of the discovery and what comes next. Extra chapters were very helpful and lead to other sources.

I didn't really understand the Higgs phenomenon so I chose to educate myself. Lisa Randall has really helped. I don't know if I am totally prepared to understand this book. The only way to find out is to try it. So far, I have enjoyed it, even if I am still a little baffled.
The book was fairly easy to read but not to simplistic.If your interested in what all the fuss is about the LHC discovery and have some knowledge of physics this is a must read.

After 20 years completing my physics degree, and with no specialization in high energy or theoretical physics, I can consider myself almost common, non specialist audience. This book by Lisa Randall, written shortly after the confirmation of the experimental evidence of the Higgs Boson from LHC experiments, is well written, and makes use of an approach that makes comprehension of such subtle matters even to non specialist audience. It makes me wish I had digged into theoretical and high energy physics back then.

Nicely written, appropriate timing, complicated for lay people especially the review of her prior book on the same general subject which I had previously read but hardly understood. Fascinating subject material. Too complicated for the general reader unless specificatly interested in this weighty absolutely limitless quest for knowlege of our Universe and it's composition.

Lisa Randall again shows her brilliant ability to make difficult subjects understandable. I have read Warped Passages and Knocking on Heaven's Door and felt in the beginning that the subject matter was so far above my head I might have to read the books on a step-ladder. To my delight I didn't need the ladder! Her book, Higgs Discovery, help me to better understand the latest advances in quantum mechanics.

I guess I expected a well organized lecture on the topic.  It could have begun with a presentation of necessary background information followed by the details of the theory and of the discovery itself presented in a logical order.  Instead it seemed a bit like a stream of consciousness diving into details, then going back to background information, then back again to details that by the end became difficult to follow.  I really enjoyed it, however, in that it offered the reaction of a particle physicist thinking about what had just happened in her field.  It had the spontenaity of the moment and that was exciting.
Rather disjointed telling of the discovery.

I desired to read all of Lisa Randall's books and wanted this one for my collection.  I recommend this book and others she writes.  This is an interesting field and perspective on these universe and scientific fields.  Thank you for a good sale and shipment experience.  Book arrived quickly and in new condition.

I give this book a five star rating because the author does a great job of explaining the issues involved, better than the other books I have read and the series of lectures I heard on the topic. A science background is useful but not necessary for understanding.

A very brief coverage of the authors initial thoughts and explanations surrounding the discovery of the Higgs boson.  Great info I didn't know about but should be nothing interesting the the informed.
Well written but not exactly for the totally un-initiated particle physics observer. It confirms just how much that is enlightened speculation.
Its a quick cash-in on the Higgs subject, pasting other materials from the same author, who happens to be a bad science communicator.
Well written discussion of the Higgs phenomena and it's impact on the physicist standard model. Recommended reading for new students.

In the book Higgs Discovery, by physicist professor Lisa Randall, we discover an example of what modern physicists understand by explanation. Professor Randall distinguishes between Higgs field, Higgs mechanism and Higgs boson. She explains that the Higgs field is something like a type of charge spread everywhere though empty space. If space if filled up by something then it is not -empty-. First logical failure. Physicists must support logical thinking, otherwise nothing makes sense. She does not explain -how- can particles without mass interact with the Higgs field and thereby adquire mass, because a particle without mass does not exist. Second logical failure. She does not explain -how- the interaction of a pre-particle with the ''Higgs charge'' produces mass. For professor Randall, it does, and that is all. Next she writes: '...add a bit of energy, and you can create an actual particle.' How do you add a bit of energy? Who is -you- that creates a particle? No, I cannot recommend this book, it does not explain anything. Like most of modern physics, is a mere decription of some phenomena produced in collissions of already massive particles at very high relative velocities (proton-proton collisions in the CERN accelerator, for instance) but the book contains no real explanation for what are the masses, contains many logical failures, and does not explain the phenomena it describes.
Hot on the trail of the Higgs discovery it explains in simple terms some of the properties of this amazing, new type of particle.
This professor must have been desperate to get another publication. The tiny book is totally worthless. Do not waste your money buying it.
The latest skinny on the Higgs boson discovery.  Short so it doesn't hurt your eyes to read on computer.
good read if you're into things that affect nonthing and everything in your life at the same type
Lisa has done it again, very good interpretation of the Higgs field discovery.
Current history of the Higgs project.  Interesting and educational reading.
Very clear, concise and knowledgeable explanation of the Higgs process

An interesting discussion of the many facets of getting to the point of being able to say we found it with statistical accuracy required in the field.  A look into what new particles can be expected to be found.  A good simplification a an extremely complex field.
Informative & well written. She knows her stuff.

This read is not for general-audiences. Struggled through the first few chapters and then gave up.  Wasted my time and money. Next time I need more information about a scientific event, I'll tune in to Brian Cox...
But it definitely requires some knowledge about science and math, especially fields, the standard model of particle physics and the possible reactions between particles.
With an interesting philosophical content. I would recomend it to every phisicist. Randall is a bright author, although not to any reader.

This is a good short read, written by someone who has their feet planted firmly on each side of the divide between a physicist and a layman.  The book is divided into two parts, initially, the author's first hand relating of the Higgs Bosen discovery and then acknowledgments backing and illuminating her story. In all a pleasant trip through the myriad paths taken by theoretical physicists on their way to this latest discovery.
ok

This ebook is especially well written and provides a great explanation of the science and significance of the Higgs discovery.  I enjoyed it enough to read in a single sitting, which is unusual for a book about science (especially physics).  I particularly liked the personal stories and anecdotes, which made an already interesting story even more compelling to read.

Ms Randall is a very good writer and handles this subject in understandable language for those of us who are not PHDs or math whizzes. a fascinating study of a reality that is hard for most to comprehend, but it is what it is, and now I have a better idea of what the physicist are doing, what motivates their curiosity.
I actually struggled through this.  I am a chemist, not a physicist, but I should have read a forward before buying it.  Too complicated.

I first read this after the July 4 hadron announcement, and found it very illuminating. True discovery was proven last week, so  i'm reading it again,to make sure I haven't missed anything,,She is a close runner up to Greene.

This book really gave me a handle on the Higgs field and higgs particle. It's a great resource on the LHC. I had been reading articles for years about the LHC, but finally this book was like a grand tour.
Dr. Randall puts a complex subject into language and concepts understandable by the general public with minimal mathematical skills. This would make a great high school science class text.
Professor Randall succeeds magnificently in making very difficult concepts readily understandable to the non-scientist. I particularly like the author's writing style.
Very nice book. I recommend it for an excellent introduction in the subject. It is well written and presents difficult concepts in a very clear way.
Well written and easily understood by folks with reasonably strong math and physics backgrounds. The illustrations make the collection simple.
Lisa does the impossible. She explains spontaneous symmetry breaking and the Higgs mechanism. This is no easy task, but she does it.
A brief but informative summary of the latest happening and signficance of the Higgs field. Not trasncendental, but an good briefing

In my opinion, the majority of intelligent laymen will not learn much about the Higgs Discovery from reading this piece. I suspect it will require someone with decent knowledge of particle physics to understand this. Yes. I know. Maybe I'm just stupid.
The book is cute and well written. It is a small little book. However, the paper quality is just normal.
Good set of shoulders to stand on. I am looking over the Higgs wall and the view is starting to clear.
I learned much that I did not know before and was left wanting to know more. I recommend this book.
It was a very good read and I enjoyed it a lot It was simple and easy to understand. Thank you.

I read HIGGS DISCOVERY to learn about something about a very esoteric subject, something we know very little about.  I read every word and finished knowing nothing.  I could not tell you anything that I did not know before I started.

Having read Lisa Randall's two previous books, Warped Passages, and Knocking On Heavens Door: How Physics and Scientific Thinking Illuminate The Modern World, I knew I was going to download this new short explication about the the wonderful discovery, 50 years after the supposition of it's existence, of the Higgs Boson, on July 4, 2012.  Now here is the thing.  Lisa Randall is a brilliant theoretical physicist, as her first two books made most clear.  It helps that she can write like a tale spinning novelist who captures you from page one and doesn't let go until the end of the book.  You simply learn about what she writes about, whether you want to or not.  That is just how good a writer she is.  But here, here, we see a different Dr Lisa Randall.  We see a human being enraptured, captured and filled with a sense of the otherworldly in how she explains what happened at CERN at the Large Hadron Collider.  You can read between the lines as she lucidly explains about the Higgs Boson, the Higgs Field and the Higgs Mechanism.  Heady stuff made crystal clear by this physicist with her heart and head in the theoretical clouds of just barely restrained excitement about the discovery and what it might portend for the Standard Model of Physics.  Or maybe not.  What it is, is this: you will easily grasp what Dr Randall writes about everything she discusses in this short, pellucid easy read.  But what I found most beautiful and extraordinary was the almost secular reverence Ms Randall has in telling all.  A delight at the possibilities and a joy in the hoping.  So, do get this lovely gem and find out why I said that Lisa Randall did it again, and aren't we the lucky ones.
very informative if a bit technical

Mostly a rehash of previous writing, offers very little real insight and is written by someone who is at best on the periphery of the work at the LHC.  Kind of looks like it was just an attempt to tap in to Higgs notoriety to raise some cash to fund another vacation in the Greek Isles, which is where the author was during some of the time the real work was going on at CERN.

Lisa Randall, can't make up her mind who this book is intended.  The inconsistant writing, self obsorbed style and lack of clarity make this book a non starter.  I don't believe she understands the subject matter.  I am sorry I wasted my time on it. ..
I am a scientist, but physics is not my field.  Sometimes I struggle to follow explanations in physics, but not with Lisa's treatise.  Thanks for getting me where I couldn't quite go before.

Duh..... What's she talking about? English please!!!!!! I just wanna know why the government has financed these colliders to find these stupid things? What's it all mean? Did the higgs boson cure HIV or cancer? Seriously! WTF!?
The author is a highly accomplished physicist, and presents the material well. I have an advanced degree in biology, but the subject matter is way beyond me.

I honestly seldom if ever read a physics book for enjoyment.  I have little knowledge of what is growing seemingly strange in this kind of work.  I don't know where this is going; I mean are we getting to the mirror yet?
